mistralai/Mistral-7B-Instruct-v0.1-4k_pr:
The Siddhartha An Indian Tale by Hermann Hesse

The son of the Brahman, Siddhartha, grew up in a house near the riverbank. He was loved by everyone, but he was not happy. He had started to feel that the love of his father and the love of his mother, and also the love of his friend, Govinda, would not bring him joy forever. He had started to suspect that the venerable Brahmans had already revealed to him the most and best of their wisdom, and the vessel was not full. He had started to feel that the ablutions and sacrifices were not enough and that he needed to find something more. He had started to feel that the self, the innermost part of the soul, was not something that could be found in the flesh and bone, the thoughts, and consciousness, but that it was something that needed to be found in a different way. He had started to feel that the only way to find the self was to practice meditation and to find the pristine source in one's own self. He had started to feel that the only way to find the self was to leave the house and to become a Samana, an ascetic on a pilgrimage.

Enoch Soames: A Memory of the Eighteen-nineties

By MAX BEERBOHM

When a book about the literature of the eighteen-nineties was given by
Mr. Holbrook Jackson to the world, I looked eagerly in the index for
Soames, Enoch. I found that he was not there.

The book was a thorough and brilliantly written work. The omission of Soames's name in the index was a deadlier record of his failure to impress himself on his decade.

Soames had failed so piteously that he was not even mentioned in the book. This was a cruel blow to his ego and a testament to his lack of success.

Despite this, I felt compelled to write about Soames. I wanted to pay tribute to his memory and to honor his contributions to literature, even if they were not widely recognized during his lifetime.

Soames was a unique individual who stood out from the crowd. He was a writer who was ahead of his time, and his ideas and concepts were often misunderstood and dismissed by his contemporaries.

Despite this, Soames persevered and continued to write, even in the face of criticism and rejection. He was a true artist who was driven by his passion for literature and his desire to express his ideas and thoughts.

Soames's legacy is one of perseverance and dedication. He was a writer who refused to give up, even when the odds were stacked against him. His work may not have been widely recognized during his lifetime, but it will continue to inspire and influence future generations of writers.

In conclusion, Enoch Soames was a remarkable individual who made a significant contribution to the literature of the eighteen-nineties. His failure to impress himself on his decade was a tragic outcome, but his legacy as a writer who persevered in the face of adversity will live on for years to come.

mistralai/Mistral-7B-Instruct-v0.1-4k_pr:
Enoch Soames A Memory of the Eighteen-nineties

By MAX BEERBOHM

When a book about the literature of the eighteen-nineties was given by
Mr. Holbrook Jackson to the world, I looked eagerly in the index for
Soames, Enoch. It was as I feared: he was not there. But everybody
else was. Many writers whom I had quite forgotten, or remembered but
faintly, lived again for me, they and their work, in Mr. Holbrook
Jackson's pages. The book was as thorough as it was brilliantly
written. And thus the omission found by me was an all the deadlier
record of poor Soames's failure to impress himself on his decade. I dare say I am the only person who noticed the omission. Soames had
failed so piteously as all that! Nor is there a counterpoise in the
thought that if he had had some measure of success he might have
passed, like those others, out of my mind, to return only at the
historian's beck. It is true that had his gifts, such as they were,
been acknowledged in his lifetime, he would never have made the bargain
I saw him make--that strange bargain whose results have kept him always
in the foreground of my memory. Not my compassion, however, impels me to write of him. For his sake, poor fellow, I should be inclined to keep my pen out of the ink. It is ill to deride the dead. And how can I write about Enoch Soames without making him ridiculous? Or, rather, how am I to hush up the horrid fact that he WAS ridiculous? I shall not be able to do that. Yet, sooner or later, write about him I must. In the summer term of '93 a bolt from the blue flashed down on Oxford. It drove deep; it hurtlingly embedded itself in the soil. Dons and undergraduates stood around, rather pale, discussing nothing but it. Wherefrom came it, this meteorite? From Paris. Its name? Will Rothenstein. Its aim? To do a series of twenty-four portraits in lithograph. These were to be published from the Bodley Head, London. The matter was urgent.
